channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Updates: International Criminal Court Issues Arrest Warrant for Putin
item.description: The court at The Hague accused the Russian president of bearing criminal responsibility for the abduction and deportation of Ukrainian children. Human rights groups praised the move, though the likelihood of an imminent arrest appeared slim.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: The International Criminal Court on Friday issued a war crimes arrest warrant for President Vladimir V. Putin.

item.title: As Dreams of Peace Wither, Nightmares Flourish in Ukraine’s Sleep
item.description: A survey asked hundreds of wartime Ukrainians what they dreamed about. Many replied: the war.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Psyches adapt to life changes in different ways. Some people recount dreams not of distress but of safety and comfort. Still others live through the trauma again in their sleep.

item.title: For Iran, Saudi Détente Could Ease Strains Regionally and at Home
item.description: Long seen as a regional troublemaker and on the defensive from advances made by Israel, Iran sees the restoration of ties with its rival as a win for all sides, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Vivian Yee
item.media:description: Ali Shamkhani, right, the secretary of Iran’s Supreme National Security Council, with Musaad al-Aiban, Saudi Arabia’s minister of state, and Wang Yi, China’s top foreign policy official, in Beijing last week.

item.title: Protests Resume in France After Macron Pushes Through Pension Bill
item.description: After President Emmanuel Macron pushed his unpopular pension bill through Parliament without a vote, demonstrations about the changes broke out again.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: A protest on Friday blocked the traffic on the périphérique, the highway that circles Paris.

item.title: Israel’s Judicial Overhaul Protests Often Begin on Apps
item.description: A movement against the government’s judicial overhaul plan is a grass-roots affair spread by word of mouth and WhatsApp messaging groups.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: A protest in Jerusalem last month against plans by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s new government to overhaul the country’s judicial system. Critics say the effort will undermine the country’s democratic institutions.

item.title: Japan-Korea Relations Improve, but Ties Are Still Fragile
item.description: Both sides face potential political snags, as well as a delicate balancing act in a region where the United States and China are competing for influence.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Takuto Kaneko/Kyodo News, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Minister Fumio Kishida of Japan and President Yoon Suk Yeol of South Korea were among a group leaving a restaurant in Tokyo on Thursday.

item.title: Xi, Cast as Peacemaker, Wades Into Russia’s War in Ukraine
item.description: China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, is expected to meet with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia next week and speak with President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Marc Santora
item.media:description: Xi Jinping in Beijing on Sunday. China’s top leader is possibly positioning himself to serve as a mediator in Russia’s war in Ukraine.

item.title: Ukraine Burns Through Ammunition in Bakhmut, Putting Future Fights at Risk
item.description: The military is using thousands of artillery shells a day as it tries to hold the eastern city, which could jeopardize a planned springtime campaign.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Lara Jakes and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: Ukraine’s use of ammunition as it tries to hold Bakhmut is so intense that the Pentagon raised concerns with Kyiv, two U.S. officials said.

item.title: Jailed in Egypt at 17, He Wrote to Survive and to Share His Long Ordeal
item.description: Sentenced as a teenager to 15 years for “unlawful assembly,” Abdelrahman ElGendy started recording the abuses of prison life. The idea of someday publishing his memoir gave him a reason to live.
item.dc:creator: Aida Alami
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Ross Mantle for The New York Times
item.media:description: Abdelrahman ElGendy, 27, in October at the University of Pittsburgh, where he is pursuing a Master of Fine Arts degree. He spent six years and three months in an Egyptian jail.

item.title: In Myanmar, Atrocities Rise as Army Comes Under Pressure
item.description: The rebellion against military rule is gaining strength, and analysts say soldiers are responding with increased brutality.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Pa-Oh National Defense Force-Kham Koung, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Bullet holes in the wall of a Buddhist monastery near the village of Nanneint in central Myanmar. Rebels who are fighting Myanmar’s army say they found 22 bodies there on Sunday.

item.title: On Italy’s Coast, Empathy Mixes With Frustration After Migrant Tragedy
item.description: As bodies continue washing up in a poverty-stricken part of Calabria, some local residents wonder whether a hard-line government understands what drives migration.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: A makeshift memorial for the victims of the migrant shipwreck in Steccato di Cutro, Italy.

item.title: Protests in Peru: How Police Used Lethal Force Against Demonstrators
item.description: A New York Times investigation found that the country’s police and military fired lethal ammunition at unarmed civilians during protests in December and January.
item.dc:creator: Brent McDonald, Ainara Tiefenthäler and James Surdam
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: An Effort to Resolve Israel’s Impasse Stalls on How to Pick Judges
item.description: Mediators say the government and its opponents agree on some changes to a judiciary overhaul plan that has divided the country. But the process of appointing new judges remains a major obstacle.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Demonstrators blocked a highway in Tel Aviv on Thursday to protest the government’s plan to overhaul the judiciary.

item.title: Dutch Pro-Farmer Party Sweeps Elections, Upsetting the Status Quo
item.description: The surprise victory is widely seen as a protest vote against Prime Minister Mark Rutte’s government and some of his policies, including a goal to slash nitrogen emissions, which many say will imperil farming operations.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.category: People's Party for Freedom and Democracy (Netherlands)
item.media:credit: Sem Van Der Wal/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Caroline van der Plas, leader of the Farmer Citizen Movement party, after the provincial election results were announced in Bathmen, the Netherlands, on Wednesday.

item.title: The U.S. has long been wary of the I.C.C., but relations have been thawing.
item.description: Many democracies have joined the court, which investigates war crimes, genocide and crimes against humanity, but Washington has been concerned that the tribunal could someday try to prosecute Americans.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: The International Criminal Court in The Hague, Netherlands.

item.title: Justice Dept. Investigating TikTok’s Owner Over Possible Spying on Journalists
item.description: The inquiry appears to be tied to an admission by the app’s owner, ByteDance, that employees had inappropriately obtained Americans’ data. The company said it had fired the workers involved.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush and Sapna Maheshwari
item.category: Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS)
item.media:description: TikTok’s U.S. offices in Culver City, Calif.

item.title: Simone Segouin, Teenage Fighter in French Resistance, Dies at 97
item.description: Portrayed in Life magazine in 1944 as a simple farm girl brandishing a submachine gun, she became a symbol of the partisans who helped defeat the Nazis.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.media:description: Simone Segouin, known by her nom de guerre, Nicole, at age 17 in 1944, after helping to capture 25 German soldiers in France. “Nothing pleased Nicole so much as the killing of the Germans,” Life magazine wrote.

item.title: Ukraine Jets: More MIG Fighters Will Help, but Kyiv Really Wants F-16s
item.description: Ukrainian officials and military analysts do not expect the MIG jets pledged so far by Poland and Slovakia to fundamentally alter the battle in the skies.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: F-16 fighter jets taking part in a NATO exercise in Poland, in October 2022.

item.title: Submarine Deal With U.S. and U.K. Sparks Debate in Australia
item.description: The agreement has raised concerns about the need for the costly plan and whether it could tether Australia to the United States.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: President Biden, along with leaders of Australia and Britain, announced plans to develop and deploy nuclear-powered attack submarines.

item.title: Search Intensifies for Radioactive Canister Missing for Weeks in Thailand
item.description: It’s not clear exactly when the 55-pound cylinder containing cesium-137 vanished from the power plant where it was in use.
item.dc:creator: Muktita Suhartono and John Yoon
item.media:credit: Prachin Buri Provincial Public Relations Office, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A photo provided by Thai authorities shows the radioactive canister in December.

item.title: Going Hungry in America
item.description: The country’s neediest are dealing with food stamp cuts and rising prices at the same time.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:description: A Dollar General in Lexington, S.C., in 2021.

item.title: Turkey Moves to Ratify Finland’s NATO Membership
item.description: Finland joining the alliance after decades of military nonalignment would be a major shift and represents a significant diplomatic and strategic defeat for Russia.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Murat Cetinmuhurdar/Presidential Press Office, via Reuters
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, left, and Finland’s president, Sauli Niinisto, in Ankara, Turkey, on Friday.

item.title: Banned From Russian Airspace, U.S. Airlines Look to Restrict Competitors
item.description: Because of the war in Ukraine, U.S. carriers have to take the long way on flights to and from Asia, giving an advantage to foreign rivals flying the same routes.
item.dc:creator: Kate Kelly and Mark Walker
item.media:credit: Vanessa Leroy for The New York Times
item.media:description: Delta Air Lines has redrawn trans-Pacific flight maps repeatedly in order to comply with both U.S. regulations and a Russian ban.

item.title: Slovakia Follows Poland in Pledging to Send Jets to Ukraine
item.description: The news came after Poland’s president said that his country would send MIG-29 jets, a move that appeared intended to open the door to more advanced warplanes from NATO allies.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: Two MIG-29 fighter jets during NATO exercises near an air base in Lask, in central Poland, last year.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Private-sector bailout for First Republic Bank.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Casey Steffens for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shares of First Republic Bank have cratered in recent days, prompting big banks, with the backing of regulators, to step in with an unusual plan.

item.title: Poland Says It Will Arm Ukraine With Warplanes, Raising Stakes
item.description: The Polish leader said he would send jets designed by the Soviet Union to help Ukraine fend off Russian forces. It was unclear if other allies might follow suit.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins and Lara Jakes
item.media:description: Polish MIG-29 fighter jets taking part in a NATO exercise last year.

item.title: Singing and Banging, French Lawmakers Vow to Stop Pension Change
item.description: Parties from the left and right erupted in anger after learning of the government’s plans to adopt the measure without a vote.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter and Constant Méheut
item.media:description: Left-wing members of France’s National Assembly held white paper signs saying “64 years, It’s a No” after a reform raising the retirement age was pushed through by a constitutional rule instead of a vote.

item.title: Macron Pushes Through Law in France Raising Retirement Age
item.description: Lacking parliamentary support, the French president used a special measure to circumvent a vote, a step likely to further enrage opponents.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: Macron Pushes Through Pension Bill
item.description: Also, Poland says it will give Ukraine warplanes and Japan extends a hand to South Korea.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: Biden to Name Nevada’s Spirit Mountain Area a National Monument
item.description: The biologically diverse land is central to the creation story of the Mojave and other tribes. Energy companies have also identified it as a prime location for wind or solar installations.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport
item.media:credit: John Burcham for The New York Times
item.media:description: Known as Avi Kwa Ame in the Mojave language, the area is home to some of the largest and oldest Joshua trees.

item.title: What’s Next for Opponents of Macron’s Retirement Plan?
item.description: A protest at Place de la Concorde in Paris began as a jovial scene, but devolved as night fell and violent protesters clashed with the police.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut and Catherine Porter
item.media:description: Protesters clashed with police clad in riot gear at the Place de la Concorde in central Paris on Thursday after the French government pushed a pension bill through Parliament without a full vote.

item.title: 3 Dogs Die After Eating Poisoned Meatballs at a Race in France
item.description: The poisonings took place at the French canicross championships, in which people run or cycle while attached to their dogs.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:description: A canicross race in the Czech Republic in 2016. Three dogs died of poisoning at a similar even in France last weekend.

item.title: HelloFresh to Stop Buying Coconut Milk From Thailand Amid Claims of Monkey Labor
item.description: The meal kit company’s decision follows an advocacy group’s report claiming that some monkeys in Thailand are forced to climb trees and pick the fruit.
item.dc:creator: Christine Chung
item.category: People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals
item.media:description: A monkey learns to collect coconuts for agriculture during a training session at the monkey school in Surat Thani, in southern Thailand.

item.title: 10 Drums of Nuclear Material Are Missing From Libya Site, U.N. Agency Says
item.description: The U.N. nuclear watchdog said that 2.5 tons of natural uranium concentrate was unaccounted for, but that the ore itself posed little radiation hazard.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: The nuclear agency’s director general, Rafael Grossi, has informed U.N. member states about the missing barrels.

item.title: U.K. Bans TikTok on Government Devices
item.description: The move reflects fears in Britain and elsewhere in the West that the popular app’s Chinese ownership could share user information with Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: The United States, Canada and India have all restricted TikTok on government devices.

item.title: Poland Says It Foiled a Russian Spy Ring
item.description: The sabotage, the Polish interior minister said, was planned “at the request of Russian intelligence” and “aimed at paralyzing the supply of equipment, weapons and aid to Ukraine.”
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: Mariusz Kaminski, Poland’s interior minister, during a visit to the Ukrainian-Polish border last year.

item.title: How Macron Is Using the French Constitution for His Pension Overhaul
item.description: A move used before by President Emmanuel Macron’s government can push bills through the lower house of Parliament without a vote. But detractors view it as an undemocratic tool to strong-arm lawmakers.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden

item.title: China’s Answer to ChatGPT Gets an Artificial Debut and Disappoints
item.description: The promised “live” demonstration of the bot had, in fact, been recorded. Shares of Baidu, the company behind the technology, tumbled in Hong Kong.
item.dc:creator: Chang Che and John Liu
item.media:description: Baidu’s chief executive, Robin Li, describing the functions of the search software’s chatbot Ernie at its debut event in Beijing on Thursday.

item.title: March Madness Is Here
item.description: A preview for fans and non-fans alike.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Caitlin Clark of the Iowa Hawkeyes.

item.title: 6 Cities on 5 Continents That Are Reimagining Urban Life
item.description: What we can learn from creative city initiatives, from Sydney to Paris.
item.dc:creator: Jenna Schnuer
item.media:credit: Esteban Vanegas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Beginning in 2004, a system of gondola lifts were installed in Medellín, Colombia, which significantly reduced commute times and cost for people in rural mountain towns.

item.title: Two Acquittals and One 18-Month Sentence in Indonesia Soccer Disaster
item.description: The defendants, all police officers, were charged with criminal negligence in connection with the October stampede that killed 135 people.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Dera Menra Sijabat
item.media:description: Police officers fired dozens of rounds of tear gas in a soccer stadium in Malang, Indonesia, on Oct. 1, an investigation found. The stampede that followed left 135 people dead.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: 近年来，瑞士信贷遭受了一次又一次的打击。

item.title: TikTok Pushed by U.S. to Resolve National Security Concerns
item.description: The demand hardens the White House’s stance toward the popular video app, which is owned by the Chinese internet company ByteDance.
item.dc:creator: David McCabe and Cecilia Kang
item.category: Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS)
item.media:credit: Ore Huiying for The New York Times
item.media:description: TikTok’s chief executive, Shou Zi Chew, in the ByteDance offices in Singapore. The White House is hardening its stance toward the Chinese-owned video app.

item.title: Israeli Government Rejects President’s Judicial Compromise
item.description: President Isaac Herzog presented an outline he had hoped would calm the country and avert a constitutional crisis, but Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu immediately rejected it.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: President Isaac Herzog of Israel in November. On Wednesday, he made an impassioned speech on the government’s proposed judicial overhaul and raised the specter of civil war.

item.title: Ukraine’s Allies Promise Weapons for Spring Counteroffensive
item.description: Ukraine and Russia are both running low on ammunition, and both are scrambling to replenish their stocks and gain a competitive edge.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Eric Schmitt, Valerie Hopkins and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier injured by shrapnel on the front line in the Donetsk region of eastern Ukraine, arriving at a stabilization point on Wednesday.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Bank Fears Resurface
item.description: Also, South Korea’s leader visits Japan and Russia gears up for more cyberattacks.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Credit Suisse has suffered blow after blow in recent years.

item.title: After 12 Years, Japan Welcomes a South Korean Leader to Tokyo
item.description: The visit, the first of its kind in 12 years, is the latest sign of a diplomatic thaw. North Korea launched a missile hours before the countries’ leaders were to meet.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol, left, and Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida meeting in Tokyo on Thursday.

item.title: Sunflower Sea Stars Are Set to Get Protection Under the Endangered Species Act
item.description: Sunflower sea stars, hit by a “climate-fueled pandemic,” play a key role in keeping marine ecosystems balanced.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn
item.media:description: Sunflower sea stars at the University of Washington laboratory in Friday Harbor. In the wild, they gorge on sea urchins.

item.title: French Protesters Rally in Last Angry Push Before Pension Bill Vote
item.description: Many believe the legislation to raise the retirement age to 64 from 62 will pass Parliament, and they are looking beyond the vote to fight on.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: Demonstrators in Lille, France, were among the hundreds of thousands who on Wednesday protested the government’s plan to raise the retirement age.

item.title: Why the Black Sea Is a Flashpoint Between Russia and the West
item.description: It has long been a theater of competition between Russia and the West, a dynamic supercharged by the Ukraine war.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Gulsin Harman
item.media:description: A Russian Navy ship entering the Black Sea through the Bosphorus strait in February 2022, before the Russian invasion of Ukraine.

item.title: Blinken Calls for ‘Accountability’ on War Crimes in Ethiopia
item.description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken walked a careful line during a visit to Ethiopia as the Biden administration reassesses relations with the prime minister, Abiy Ahmed.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and Declan Walsh
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken arriving in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, on Tuesday.

item.title: Russia’s Spring Offensive in Ukraine Could Include Cyberattacks, Microsoft Says
item.description: Moscow also appears to be stepping up influence operations to weaken European and U.S. support for sending more aid to the Ukrainian government.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, David E. Sanger and Marc Santora
item.media:description: Even as Russian cyberoperations appear poised to intensify, Ukrainian defenses, at least for now, remain strong, according to U.S. and Ukrainian officials.

item.title: Teachers Join Wave of Public Service Strikes as U.K. Unveils Budget
item.description: A two-day strike by educators in England coincided with walkouts by doctors and transit staff. And it began on the day that the government detailed its new budget.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Teachers in England went on a two-day strike on Wednesday, joining in work stoppages by health care and transport workers, who have organized strikes of their own this week.

item.title: Israel Says It Killed a Bomber Who Probably Entered From Lebanon
item.description: Officials said that the man was behind a roadside blast in northern Israel, most likely after having crossed the border secretly, in a rare incident along the frontier.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Ronen Bergman and Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Israeli forces on the border with Lebanon in January. Tensions on the Israeli-Lebanese border had been kept in relative check over the past decade.
